deliberation: Checked the chronological formula for figurative elements. The only potentially figurative part is the standard prophetic formula 'the word of YHWH came to me', which treats the divine word as something that can come or arrive. This is a conventional metaphor/personification for prophetic revelation.

instances.english_text: the word of GOD came to me
ground: The initiative and directedness of God's communication to the prophet
Shared sense of purposeful approach
Communication/relational domain
posture: Depicts revelation as active and intrusive, not passive
instances.explanation: The abstract 'word of YHWH' is portrayed as something that can 'come' to the prophet, personifying and metaphorically spatializing divine speech as an approaching entity.

deliberation: Examined address 'son of man', command to prophesy, and the phrase 'set your face against Pharaoh'. The command uses bodily orientation as a metaphorical idiom for hostile stance; the rest is straightforward.

instances.english_text: turn/set your face against Pharaoh king of Egypt
vehicle: Facing someone with one’s face directed at them
ground: Deliberate, confrontational stance toward an opponent
Shared sense of directed opposition
Conflict/hostility domain
posture: YHWH instructs the prophet to adopt a confrontational posture toward Pharaoh
instances.explanation: The prophet is not literally just changing his physical orientation; the bodily image of 'setting the face against' expresses an attitude of determined opposition and judgment.

deliberation: Considered the identification of Pharaoh with a 'great tannin' in the Nile and the boast 'My Nile is mine, and I made it/myself'. The first is a clear animal/chaos-monster metaphor; the second is a boastful, likely hyperbolic claim to creative power and ownership.

instances.hebrew_text: פַּרְעֹה מֶלֶךְ־מִצְרַיִם הַתַּנִּים הַגָּדוֹל הָרֹבֵץ בְּתוֹךְ יְאֹרָיו
instances.english_text: Pharaoh king of Egypt, the great monster, sprawling in the midst of his channels
vehicle: The great tannin (sea monster/crocodile) lying in the Nile channels
ground: Power, dominance over the Nile system and people, arrogance, and threat
Shared traits of might, territorial control, and menace
Rule/oppression domain
posture: YHWH’s hostile re-characterization of Pharaoh as a beast to be hunted and subdued
instances.explanation: Pharaoh is metaphorically equated with a great Nile-creature, evoking both the crocodile and the mythic chaos-monster, to depict him as a proud, dangerous force entrenched in his river system.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁר אָמַר לִי יְאֹרִי וַאֲנִי עֲשִׂיתִנִי
instances.english_text: who said, ‘My Nile is my own; I made it for myself’ (or: ‘and I made myself’)
target: Pharaoh’s claim to ownership/creative power over the Nile (and himself)
vehicle: A creator-god who brings the Nile (and himself) into being
ground: Excessive claim to ultimate sovereignty, self-origination, and control over life-giving waters
Shared idea of absolute creative authority
Pride/arrogance domain
posture: Quoted speech to expose Pharaoh’s hubris as overblown and blasphemous
instances.explanation: Pharaoh’s boast that the Nile is his and that he ‘made’ it/himself is a hyperbolic metaphor of self-deification and absolute control, attributing to himself creator-like status over Egypt’s lifeline.

deliberation: This verse extends the monster imagery: hooks in jaws, fish sticking to scales, and hauling the creature from the Nile. It is not a literal fishing scene but a sustained metaphor for God’s capture of Pharaoh and the removal of his dependents/allies.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתִּי חַחִים בִּלְחָיֶיךָ וְהִדְבַּקְתִּי דְגַת־יְאֹרֶיךָ בְּקַשְׂקְשֹׂתֶיךָ וְהַעֲלִיתִיךָ מִתּוֹךְ יְאֹרֶיךָ וְאֵת כָּל־דְּגַת יְאֹרֶיךָ בְּקַשְׂקְשֹׂתֶיךָ תִּדְבָּק
instances.english_text: I will put hooks in your jaws, and make the fish of your channels cling to your scales; I will haul you up from your channels, with all the fish of your channels clinging to your scales.
target: Pharaoh’s forced removal from his secure power base along with his attached people/allies
Humiliation and displacement of a ruler with his followers
vehicle: A great fish/monster hooked in the jaws and dragged from the water with other fish stuck to its scales
Fishing/hunting of a large aquatic animal and its attached fish
ground: Being forcibly seized from a secure environment, helpless against the captor, with dependent followers dragged out with him
Shared notions of inescapable capture and the fate of those attached to a leader
Conquest/subjugation domain
posture: YHWH positions himself as master-hunter humiliating Pharaoh and exposing his dependent network
Assertion of divine control over political powers
instances.explanation: Hooks in the jaws and fish clinging to the scales continue the earlier monster metaphor: Pharaoh is treated as a great fish dragged from the Nile, and ‘fish’ metonymically represent his people or allies who will be carried into the same downfall.

deliberation: Still within the monster imagery: casting into the wilderness and becoming food for beasts and birds. While unburied corpses eaten by animals can be literal after battle, here it is framed within the fish/monster picture, functioning as a metaphor for disgraceful death and exposure.

instances.hebrew_text: וּנְטַשְׁתִּיךָ הַמִּדְבָּרָה ... לְחַיַּת הָאָרֶץ וּלְעוֹף הַשָּׁמַיִם נְתַתִּיךָ לְאָכְלָה
instances.english_text: I will fling you into the desert ... I have given you as food to the beasts of the earth and the birds of the sky.
target: Pharaoh and Egypt’s ignominious defeat and unprotected exposure
Political downfall and shameful death of a nation/king
vehicle: A carcass of a great creature and fish thrown on land as carrion for wild animals and birds
ground: Shame, helplessness, and being utterly at the mercy of others after death/defeat
Shared image of dishonor and total vulnerability
Shame/humiliation domain
posture: YHWH depicts Pharaoh’s end as dishonorable carrion, signaling contempt and total reversal of status
instances.explanation: Casting Pharaoh and the ‘fish’ onto the field as food for beasts and birds extends the metaphor: Egypt’s ruler and his people are pictured as carcasses exposed to scavengers, representing the disgrace and helplessness of their defeat.

deliberation: Looked for imagery in the rationale clause. The key expression is 'you were a staff of reed to the house of Israel', clearly metaphorical and also a conventional prophetic idiom for Egypt as an unreliable support.

instances.hebrew_text: יַעַן הֱיוֹתָם מִשְׁעֶנֶת קָנֶה לְבֵית יִשְׂרָאֵל
instances.english_text: Because you were a staff of reed to the House of Israel
target: Egypt as a political ally of Israel
vehicle: A reed-staff used for leaning on
ground: Outward appearance of help but actual weakness and unreliability, prone to breaking
Shared idea of deceptive support that fails under pressure
Trust/security domain
posture: YHWH rebukes Egypt’s role as a false support for Israel
instances.explanation: Egypt is likened to a ‘reed-staff’—a walking stick made of fragile reed—conveying that dependence on Egypt for support leads to collapse because the ally is inherently weak.

deliberation: This verse elaborates the reed-staff image: grasping it causes it to splinter and wound shoulders; leaning on it causes it to break and make loins unstable. These actions extend one coherent metaphor of Egypt as an injurious, unreliable support, not multiple unrelated figures.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּתָפְשָׂם בְּךָ בַכַּף תֵּרוֹץ וּבָקַעְתָּ לָהֶם כָּל־כָּתֵף וּבְהִשָּׁעֲנָם עָלֶיךָ תִשָּׁבֵר וְהַעֲמַדְתָּ לָהֶם כָּל־מָתְנָיִם
instances.english_text: When they grasped you with the hand, you would splinter and wound all their shoulders; and when they leaned on you, you would break and make all their loins unsteady.
target: Israel’s political reliance on Egypt that results in harm and instability
vehicle: Grasping and leaning on a brittle staff that breaks, splinters, and injures the one depending on it
ground: The more one relies on this support, the more it fails and causes injury instead of help
Shared traits of collapse under pressure and resulting harm
Consequence-of-misplaced-trust domain
posture: YHWH retrospectively interprets Israel’s experience as a cautionary picture of misplaced trust
instances.explanation: Egypt remains the reed-staff of v.6; the description of splintering and injuring shoulders and loins graphically portrays how dependence on Egypt harmed Israel instead of supporting them.

deliberation: The main imagery is 'I am bringing a sword against you'. This is conventional prophetic language using 'sword' metonymically for war/invasion and metaphorically for violent judgment.

instances.english_text: I am bringing a sword against you
target: Impending military invasion and devastation of Egypt
vehicle: A literal sword being brought against someone
ground: Lethal, cutting, destructive nature of the coming judgment
Shared ideas of death-dealing attack
Punitive-violence domain
posture: YHWH frames the coming invasion as his own hostile act of bringing a weapon against Egypt
instances.explanation: The ‘sword’ stands metonymically for invading armies and metaphorically for the violent judgment God will execute, not merely for a single literal blade.

deliberation: The desolation terminology can be largely literal. The notable figurative element is again Pharaoh’s boast about the Nile: 'The Nile is mine and I made it', echoing v.3, expressing arrogant, hyperbolic self-claim to creator-like power.

instances.hebrew_text: יַעַן אָמַר יְאֹר לִי וַאֲנִי עָשִׂיתִי
instances.english_text: because he said, ‘The Nile is mine, and I made it.’
target: Pharaoh’s claim of absolute ownership and origination of Egypt’s life-source
vehicle: A creator and proprietor of the Nile
ground: Inappropriately claiming ultimate control and authorship over what is in fact God’s domain
Shared notion of final authority and origination
Arrogance/domain-usurpation
posture: YHWH cites this boast as evidence of intolerable pride warranting judgment
instances.explanation: Pharaoh’s assertion that he ‘made’ the Nile is a hyperbolic, figurative claim of godlike creative status, functioning as the theological rationale for Egypt’s devastation.

deliberation: Most of the verse is literal threat. The phrase 'from Migdol to Syene, and up to the border of Cush' is a geographical merism expressing the total north-south extent of Egypt rather than just those endpoints.

instances.english_text: from Migdol to Syene, all the way to the border of Cush
vehicle: Named northern and southern extremities of Egypt
ground: Endpoints used to imply everything in between, signaling comprehensiveness
Shared notion of total coverage between extremes
Totality/wholeness domain
posture: YHWH emphasizes that no part of Egypt’s land is exempt from the coming devastation
instances.explanation: By citing the extreme locations ‘from Migdol to Syene … to the border of Cush’, the text uses a merism—endpoints standing for the whole—to signify that the entire country will become desolate.

deliberation: Evaluated the statement about no human or animal foot passing through and forty years of uninhabited land. The 'no foot' formula is a standard hyperbolic way to depict extreme desolation, not necessarily an insistence on literal absolute absence of any step.

instances.hebrew_text: לֹא תַעֲבֹר־בָּהּ רֶגֶל אָדָם וְרֶגֶל בְּהֵמָה לֹא תַעֲבֹר־בָּהּ
instances.english_text: No human foot shall traverse it, and no animal foot shall traverse it
target: The severity of Egypt’s desolation and depopulation
Absence of normal life and traffic
vehicle: The total absence of any human or animal footfall
Feet as indicators of travelers and inhabitants
ground: Where no one passes, there is no habitation or normal activity
Shared idea that lack of footprints signals emptiness
Desolation/emptiness domain
posture: YHWH uses vivid overstatement to stress the utter ruin of the land
instances.explanation: Feet of humans and beasts stand metonymically for their presence; the claim that no foot at all will pass is hyperbolic idiom for extraordinary devastation and abandonment.

deliberation: Observed two types of figurative expression: (1) superlative 'most desolate of desolate lands / ruined cities', which functions as intensifying hyperbole, and (2) scattering Egypt among the nations, drawing on the metaphor of scattering objects/seeds for dispersion of people.

instances.hebrew_text: שְׁמָמָה בְּתוֹךְ אֲרָצוֹת נְשַׁמּוֹת ... עָרֶיהָ בְּתוֹךְ עָרִים מָחֳרָבוֹת תִּהְיֶינָה שְׁמָמָה
instances.english_text: I will make the land of Egypt the most desolate of desolate lands, and its cities shall be the most desolate of ruined cities.
target: Degree of Egypt’s devastation relative to other lands
ground: Repetition and superlative construction heighten the sense of unparalleled devastation
Shared idea of extremity via overstatement
Evaluation/intensity domain
posture: The speaker stresses that Egypt’s ruin will be exceptionally severe, not ordinary
instances.explanation: The repeated superlative expressions do not merely state ruin but exaggerate its degree for emphasis, marking this as rhetorical hyperbole.

instances.english_text: I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations and disperse them throughout the countries.
target: Forced dispersion of the Egyptian population by exile and displacement
vehicle: Scattering and winnowing objects (e.g., grain, chaff, seed)
ground: Individuals of the nation are treated like particles cast widely and separated
Shared notion of being broken up and spread out with loss of cohesion
Loss-of-cohesion/dispersal domain
posture: YHWH portrays the exile of Egyptians as his active scattering, underscoring his control over their fate
instances.explanation: The verbs for scattering and dispersing draw on imagery of tossing many small items so they spread apart; people are conceptualized as such particles, depicting exile as a divinely driven scattering.

deliberation: This verse speaks of gathering Egypt from the peoples where they were scattered. The 'gathering' uses the same conceptual metaphor as with Israel’s exiles: people treated as dispersed elements to be collected together.

instances.english_text: I will gather the Egyptians from the peoples among whom they were dispersed.
target: Reconstitution of the dispersed Egyptian population
vehicle: Gathering scattered items back into one place
ground: Dispersed individuals are conceptualized like scattered objects that can be re-collected into a unified group
Shared idea of restoring scattered elements to unity
Cohesion/restoration domain
posture: YHWH presents himself as the one who actively re-collects Egypt after judgment
instances.explanation: The verb ‘gather’ treats scattered people analogously to scattered objects being picked up and brought together, figuratively describing national restoration.

deliberation: Identified two figurative elements: (1) 'restore the fortunes' (shavti et-shevut) as a conventional idiom for reversing disaster, and (2) describing Egypt as a 'lowly kingdom', using vertical imagery (low/high) to depict political status.

instances.english_text: I will restore the fortunes of the Egyptians
target: Egypt’s changed condition from calamity to relative well-being
vehicle: Reversing a state as if it were an object or condition to be turned
ground: Disaster is conceptualized as a ‘turning’ or state that can be reversed or turned back
Shared notion of directional change representing improved circumstances
Reversal/renewal domain
posture: YHWH portrays himself as the one who can reverse even severe judgment
instances.explanation: The idiom literally ‘turn the turning/fortune’ uses spatial reversal as a metaphor for undoing calamity and bringing about better conditions.

instances.english_text: and there they shall be a lowly kingdom
target: Egypt’s reduced political status among other nations
ground: Lower physical position evokes lesser importance, rank, or power
Shared mapping of low height to low status
Status hierarchy domain
posture: The speaker underlines that Egypt’s restoration will be modest and subordinated, not glorious
instances.explanation: Calling Egypt a 'low' kingdom uses the common metaphor of verticality, where low height stands for diminished status and lack of prominence.

deliberation: Continues the vertical-status metaphor from v.14: 'the lowliest of kingdoms' and 'shall not again exalt itself over the nations'. This is one coherent metaphorical mapping of height to political status.

instances.hebrew_text: מִן־הַמַּמְלָכוֹת תִּהְיֶה שְׁפָלָה וְלֹא־תִתְנַשֵּׂא עוֹד עַל־הַגּוֹיִם
instances.english_text: It shall be the lowliest of all the kingdoms, and shall not lord it over (exalt itself above) the nations again.
target: Egypt’s potential role and standing vis-à-vis other kingdoms
vehicle: Being low vs. rising/exalting oneself above others
ground: Physical height represents superiority; lowness represents inferiority or subordination
Shared conceptual mapping of up = more power, down = less power
Authority/status domain
posture: YHWH declares a capped ceiling on Egypt’s future power, constraining its ability to dominate
instances.explanation: The language of being ‘low’ and not ‘exalting’ itself pictures Egypt’s political role in terms of vertical placement, using spatial metaphors to express hierarchy of power.

deliberation: Searched for imagery. The main figurative element is Egypt as a 'trust' (mivtach) for Israel, i.e., a supposed place/object of security. Egypt (a nation) is conceptualized as something one leans on for safety, extending the earlier reed-staff motif.

instances.english_text: Never again shall they be the trust of the House of Israel
target: Egypt as an object of Israel’s hoped-for security
vehicle: A 'trust' or place/object one counts on for safety
ground: Nation treated as if it were a refuge or stronghold in which one can feel secure
Shared sense of providing (or failing to provide) safety
Risk/assurance domain
posture: YHWH disqualifies Egypt from ever again serving as Israel’s perceived refuge
Insistence on trust in YHWH alone
instances.explanation: Calling Egypt a ‘trust’ portrays the nation as an object/place of security; it’s a metaphor highlighting that Israel wrongly treated a political ally as their ultimate refuge.

deliberation: Structurally parallel to v.1: a date plus 'the word of YHWH came to me'. The same conventional metaphor/personification of the divine word as something that can 'come' is present.

instances.english_text: the word of GOD came to me
vehicle: A word that comes/arrives at a person
ground: God’s speech is portrayed as actively approaching the prophet, not as passive information
Shared notion of intentional approach and encounter
Communication/encounter domain
posture: Underscores the initiative and authority of divine revelation
instances.explanation: As in v.1, the abstract divine 'word' is personified as something that ‘comes’ to Ezekiel, using movement language as a metaphor for revelation.

deliberation: Considered whether 'every head is rubbed bald and every shoulder scraped' is literal or figurative. In prophetic rhetoric, this is best taken as hyperbolic imagery for the severe toil and wear of a prolonged siege, using body parts synecdochically for the whole army’s exhaustion.

instances.english_text: every head is rubbed bald and every shoulder scraped
target: The extreme labor and hardship endured by Nebuchadrezzar’s army in the siege of Tyre
vehicle: Bald heads and raw shoulders from wearing helmets and carrying burdens
ground: Visible bodily damage signifies protracted, arduous toil
Shared idea of hardship expressed through bodily strain
Suffering/exertion domain
posture: YHWH acknowledges the costly labor of the Babylonian army as justification for recompense
instances.explanation: The description that 'every' head and shoulder is damaged exaggerates for effect and uses heads/shoulders as synecdoche for the soldiers’ whole persons, picturing grueling siege work.

deliberation: Reviewed verbs and nouns (carry off wealth, spoil, booty, wages). These terms can be taken literally in a military context without clear figurative extension beyond normal war language. No distinct metaphor or other figure seems required.

Assessed whether 'wage' language is figurative. It can be understood straightforwardly: Egypt’s land/wealth functions as real recompense for Babylon’s historically actual labor in God’s service. The conceptualization is analogical but not strongly figurative in form; no clear metaphor beyond normal pay/compensation vocabulary.

Identified two distinct figures: (1) 'I will cause a horn to sprout for the house of Israel'—a standard metaphor where horn = strength/power and sprouting = growth; (2) 'I will give you an opening of mouth in their midst'—metaphor for authorized, bold speech and vindicated prophetic role.

instances.english_text: I will cause a horn to sprout for the House of Israel
target: Renewed power and honor for the people of Israel
vehicle: A horn that sprouts or grows like a plant
ground: A horn symbolizes strength/kingship; sprouting imagery conveys emergence and increase
Shared ideas of growing, visible power and exaltation
Flourishing/victory domain
posture: YHWH promises a fresh emergence of strength for Israel after judgment
instances.explanation: ‘Horn’ is a metonym for power or royal might, and its ‘sprouting’ uses growth imagery to portray the emergence and increase of Israel’s restored strength.

instances.english_text: and you I will give an opening of mouth in their midst
target: Ezekiel’s vindicated, free, and authoritative prophetic speech among Israel
vehicle: An opened mouth, or the act of opening the mouth
ground: Opening the mouth stands for empowered, unrestrained speaking with authority
Shared notion of access and boldness in speech
Expression/authorization domain
posture: YHWH commits to publicly legitimizing the prophet’s voice at the time of Israel’s restoration
instances.explanation: The 'opening of the mouth' metaphorically denotes Ezekiel’s divinely granted opportunity and boldness to speak, signaling the end of opposition or restraint and the recognition of his message.
